thread.title: Middlesbrough 3-2 Oxford: Heartbreak for League One side as Cristhian Stuani hits late winner - 5 things we learned
thread.title_full: Middlesbrough 3-2 Oxford: Heartbreak for League One side as Cristhian Stuani hits late winner - 5 things we learned

author: Simon Bird
title: Middlesbrough 3-2 Oxford: Heartbreak for League One side as Cristhian Stuani hits late winner - 5 things we learned
text:
Cristhian Stuani ht the winner (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share Get football   Could   
Sub Crithian Stuani rescued Boro with a late winner – after an amazing Oxford comeback. 
Antonio Martinez scored Oxford's second goal in 60 seconds to earn what looked like a deserved replay. 
But Stuani came off the bench, and tapped home in the 87th minute, after fellow sub Alvaro Negredo hooked into his path. 
Michael Appleton's side bossed the second half – and over-turned a 2-0 deficit. 
Martinez netted in the 65th muinute, blasting home Brad Guzan's parry after Chris Maguire's shot. 
Maguire's free kick had given United hope just a minute earlier. 
Rudy Gestede looked to have sealed Boro's place in the last eight. Middlesbrough booked their place in the quarter-finals (Photo: REUTERS) 
Grant Leadbitter opened the scoring with a penalty won by Stewart Downing. 
Then Gestede made it two, with an overhead kick from Fabio's cross that sealed the game. 
The drama was far from over. Karanka says he loves the cup but almost pays price for making changes 
There can be no doubting that Aitor Karanka respects the cup, having flown over Wembley a few years ago and decided to “win something” at the stadium. 
But he made seven changes for this game. He wants to use the cup as an “incentive” for his squad players who are pushing to start in the league. 
Trouble is many of his players were not good enough here in the second half, after cruising to a comfortable lead. Aitor Karanka almost saw his side crash out (Photo: REUTERS) Are alarm bells ringing at Boro's poor form? 
Chairman Steve Gibson sat stern faced, looking miserable, in the directors box as Oxford made their come back. 
He needn't have worried. 
This was Boro's third win of the year... all have come in the cup which is proving a lifeline for Karanka and the fans. 
A run of one win in 11 in the league needs to change quickly. Oxford's best FA Cup show for 23 years, but it ends here 
Not since 1994, when they lost to Chelsea, had Oxford reached the 5th round stage. 
A win would have won only their second quarter final appearance, the last in 1964 when they lost to Preston. 
They looked finished at half time but boss Michael Appleton must have made a brilliant team talk to spark such a comeback. 
His side deserved a relay but one late lapse and they were denied. Oxford had fought back from 2-0 down (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Oxford comeback sparked by Maguire free kick goal.. 
Chris Maguire made amends for conceding a penalty by getting Oxford back in the game. 
He curled in a great free kick from 18 yards out, dinking over the defensive wall, after being fouled by Adama Traore. Brad Guzan was poorly positioned. 
Within a minute Oxford were level, thanks to Antonio Martinez. 
Maguire was influential again, getting into a dangerous position on the left of the box and smashing a shot that Guzan couldn't hold. Chris Maguire scored a stunning free-kick... (Photo: REUTERS) ... but his joy turned to dejection (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Martinez mopped up the rebound. 
United were also denied a first half goal. 
Kane Hemmings was pressurising Bernado when Maguire dinked a good ball inside the back line. 
Bernado tripped and slid out a leg as the ball flew into the net. Referee Andre Marriner judged the Boro defender had been tripped. January signing Rudy Gestede gets his first goal 
Karanka wants him to pressure Alvaro Negredo for the starting striker berth, and he's doing just that. 
He scored a lovely overhead kick after Fabio's cross caused confusion in the visiting defence. 
It was an improvised goal and Negredo, on the bench, will have taken not that more is needed from him in the league in the coming weeks. 
Indeed Negredo came on late, and helped make the winner. That's the sort of competition for places Boro need. Rudy Gestede finally broke his duck for Boro (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Like us on Facebook
